articles.content:
Trump ties crime with immigration, blurring the lines with Guard deployment 
         By Kat Lonsdorf, Sergio Martínez-Beltrán 
        
           Friday, October 17, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         CHICAGO — It's a sunny October morning, and Yackson is waiting for a bus that will take him to meet his immigration attorney. The Venezuelan, who NPR is identifying by his first name because of his immigration status, looks at a big, run-down apartment building in front of him. Earlier this month, it was raided by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents who landed a helicopter on the roof, and arrested more than 30 people. Yackson, 39, says he's terrified. Besides this raid, he's also heard about the possibility of National Guard troops deploying here, something a federal court has put on hold for now. The father of three lives in this neighborhood and he's been scared to leave his house. "We already don't know who is grabbing us, whether it's ICE or whether it's people who disguise themselves as ICE," Yackson says in Spanish. "With the National Guard, it's going to be even harder, scarier." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In several cities across the country facing National Guard deployments, NPR has heard similar sentiment. "The government isn't exactly doing a great job of proactively delineating this person is National Guard who isn't allowed to arrest immigrants, and this person is an ICE agent or an FBI agent who is," says Dara Lind a senior fellow at the American Immigration Council, noting that many times federal agents are in military-style gear, or masked, or not clearly marked. She says this makes it hard to look at patrols on the street and figure out who is legally authorized to engage in law enforcement activities or not. Under U.S. law, the National Guard and other military personnel can't make arrests. But experts worry that the pattern of their deployments, alongside increased federal immigration raids and operations, has allowed for violent crime and illegal immigration to be conflated into a single crisis. The Guard's actual role in immigration enforcement in these deployments remains unclear. In September, the Trump administration announced a widespread ICE operation in Illinois called Operation Midway Blitz, saying it was needed to fight crime by undocumented immigrants. It came after Trump had been pressuring Democratic Illinois Governor JB Pritzker to deploy the state National Guard for the same reason, but Pritzker refused. After weeks of fighting between the two, Trump federalized the Illinois National Guard – a highly unusual move — and worked with Republican Texas Governor Greg Abbott to send hundreds of his state's Guard to Illinois. Part of Trump's continued rhetoric Trump has been  conflating crime and illegal immigration  since he first emerged on the political scene. It's something that has proved popular with his base — and helped garner support for his  unprecedented crackdown on immigrants . The net has swept up people living in the country illegally along with U.S. residents, people with visas, or those granted humanitarian parole. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The White House regularly characterizes undocumented immigrants as drivers of urban lawlessness,  even though the data show that is not true . Officials at the Department of Homeland Security and the White House constantly refer to ICE actions as only targeting " the worst of the worst ," a talking point that isn't  supported by the arrest data . "This is really, really core to the administration's immigration policy. They toggle between 'we're only going after these really, really bad criminals,' and 'we're deporting everybody who's in the country without authorization,'" says Lind. "They get to play that two-step because there's this bigger body of fears that they're playing into about urban areas as unsafe, as unruly, about there being some kind of unrest, and about protests being always akin to riots." Trump has deployed  the National Guard in five Democratic-led cities  so far — often over the objections of state and local leaders — claiming troops are needed to control crime and lawlessness, although data show that violent crime in many of those places has decreased in recent years. Some of those deployments — like in  Chicago  and  Portland, Ore.  — have been blocked by the courts and are making their way through a federal appeals process. But others are ongoing, like in Washington, D.C., and Memphis. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       These deployments have coincided with increased immigration raids which have, in effect, blurred the lines between traditional law enforcement, immigration enforcement and the role of the National Guard. In June,  Trump federalized California's National Guard  — against Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom's wishes – and sent in members of the U.S. Marine Corps to quell protests in Los Angeles in response to increased immigration and deportation raids in the city. There, protesters confined to an area of downtown Los Angeles clashed with federal agents. And ICE  often launched raids  at Home Depot stores and other locations across the city. A federal judge in California  later ruled  that the National Guard troops were being used illegally there, violating the  Posse Comitatus Act , a 19th-century law that bars the use of federal troops for domestic policing, except when "expressly authorized by the Constitution or Act of Congress." Trump appealed that ruling, and a hearing is expected later this month. Trump has also deployed troops to guard federal agents who are carrying out immigration enforcement operations. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In August, Trump sent National Guard troops into Washington, D.C., a unique place where Trump has the legal authority to do so, along with a flood of federal law enforcement agents, including ICE, which has carried out a  sizable chunk of the arrests . The next month,  Trump announced a similar operation in Memphis  — with the support of Republican Governor Bill Lee, who approved the use of Tennessee National Guard troops. The deployment started at the end of September and is ongoing. The operation also includes officials from more than a dozen federal agencies, including ICE, and has led to more than 800 arrests, according to the Department of Justice. While the DOJ has not released a breakdown of that data, Shelby County Mayor Lee Harris, who has been critical of the federal intervention,  noted at a press conference this week  that immigration offenses made up a significant portion of the arrests. Immigration and National Guard deployments are "deeply intertwined" In Illinois, Texas National Guard troops were briefly stationed at an ICE facility outside of Chicago, before their deployment was temporarily blocked. In D.C., troops have mainly been cleaning up streets and guarding federal buildings. In Memphis, they've been seen accompanying local law enforcement. But legal experts say there's a clear connection developing between Trump's use of the troops and his immigration enforcement tactics. "We see these as deeply intertwined," says Benjamin Farley, special counsel at the National Immigration Law Center, which advocates for immigrant rights. "The Trump administration is using an increasingly aggressive, increasingly brutal approach to immigration enforcement, which, unsurprisingly, inspires protests. And then the protests themselves serve as a pretext or an excuse for the Trump administration to deploy the National Guard and the Armed Forces of the United States," he says. The Texas National Guard — which has been federalized and deployed to Illinois, even as the deployment is challenged in court — has been involved in immigration-related operations in the past. In 2021, Gov. Abbott sent hundreds of troops to the Texas-Mexico border to assist in his multibillion dollar initiative called  Operation Lone Star . Among the tasks for the troops were repelling migrants and, at least in one instance, troops used tear gas on a group of Venezuelan migrants at the border. That operation is still ongoing. Scott R. Anderson, a fellow specializing in national security law at the non-partisan Brookings Institution, notes that the way Trump seems to be using the National Guard now — largely guarding federal property — is not as dramatic as a lot of the rhetoric surrounding the deployments. Still, he says that it is pushing the envelope of the law, and could gradually change with further deployments. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "I think precisely because it's unprecedented and because it's on uncertain legal territory, the administration is actually doing it kind of incrementally, they're not immediately jumping to the most severe thing they could be doing. And that makes just a more complicated picture, and it also complicates how you respond to it in a lot of ways," he says. But the legal grounds for the deployments aren't something many people caught up in them have the luxury of thinking about, says Lind of the American Immigration Council. For communities who are targeted and already frightened, taking the time to differentiate between the National Guard and a federal law enforcement agency is secondary to staying safe. "I don't think a whole lot of people are particularly interested in parsing the relationship between the National Guard and federal law enforcement," she says.  NPR's Marisa Peñaloza contributed to this report from Chicago.  
         
         Transcript 
         AILSA CHANG, HOST:   President Trump's National Guard deployments have been blurring the lines between crime patrols and illegal immigration enforcement. Guard troops have been sent to help with immigration enforcement, including securing federal ICE facilities and in some cases protecting ICE agents during raids. The White House frequently characterizes undocumented immigrants as drivers of urban lawlessness, even though the data shows that is not true. Here to talk about all of this is NPR's Sergio Martínez-Beltrán in Chicago and NPR's Kat Lonsdorf in D.C. Hey to both of you. KAT LONSDORF, BYLINE: Hey there. SERGIO MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN, BYLINE: Hey, Ailsa. CHANG: Sergio, let's start with you. Just catch us up on what's been happening on the ground in Chicago the last few days. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Well, Ailsa, the National Guard is in Illinois. More specifically, the Texas National Guard is in Illinois, along with some federalized Illinois guard. But you won't see them out in the streets of Chicago, though. That's because a federal court temporarily blocked its deployment yesterday. Now, the only place that troops were sent in Illinois so far is an ICE processing facility outside of Chicago. I went there and not much was happening. CHANG: OK. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Now, last month, ICE launched a new operation here in Chicago, claiming it was needed to fight off crime - something state and local leaders strongly refute. Chicago has its ongoing challenges with crime - right? - but the city's homicide rate this summer was the lowest since 1965. But this is what Trump has been doing since he first emerged on the political scene - deliberately conflating these ideas of crime and illegal immigration, which has proved popular with his base and helped to garner support for his unprecedented crackdown on immigrants - those in the country illegally and, in some cases, people who are U.S. residents or have visas. CHANG: OK. Well, Kat, you've been following these various National Guard deployments or threats of deployments the past few weeks. LONSDORF: Yeah. CHANG: Can you just talk about the larger pattern you're seeing here? LONSDORF: Yeah. I mean, Trump's conflation of crime and illegal immigration has been at the center of many of these deployments. We first saw it back in June, when Trump federalized California's National Guard against Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom's wishes. Trump did that to quell protests in Los Angeles in response to immigration and deportation raids in the city. The Guard was sent in to protect federal ICE facilities and personnel in that case too. And that's the same reasoning Trump has given for federalizing the Guard in Oregon as well, even though that is currently halted by the federal courts, too. Experts we've talked to say these National Guard deployments and the administration's immigration tactics are pretty intertwined right now. Here's Benjamin Farley with the National Immigration Law Center, which advocates for immigrant rights. BENJAMIN FARLEY: Using the aggressive and sort of brutal approach to immigration enforcement, generating a very expected reaction and then letting that reaction serve as a pretext for the deployment of armed forces. LONSDORF: And, you know, legally speaking, when the National Guard is federalized, which is the case in all these Democratic states where the governors have pushed back, they can't enforce state laws unless the governors say they can. CHANG: That's right. And let's be very clear here. Even if the president says that these troops are going to help fight crime in these various places, let's remember that the National Guard cannot make arrests. They cannot, like, join up with local law enforcement officers to fight crime, right? LONSDORF: Right. But they can help immigration enforcement even if they still can't make arrests because that's federal. Here's how Scott R. Anderson at the nonpartisan Brookings Institution explained it. SCOTT R ANDERSON: He's trying to get them to consent to doing a broader mission set. But until they do, he's doing this narrow one to focus on immigration law 'cause that's what he has the legal authority to do. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: And Ailsa, there's something else that's significant here. It was Texas Governor Greg Abbott who sent his National Guard troops to Illinois at Trump's request. And the Texas guard, contrary to other state guards, has been involved in immigration operations. Abbott sent troops to the Texas-Mexico border to repel migrants as part of a multibillion-dollar effort called Operation Lone Star. I mean, there's footage of troops using tear gas on a group of Venezuelan migrants at the border in 2024. So the Texas guard has done immigration-related work before, and that could impact how they'd operate if allowed to patrol on the streets here in Illinois. CHANG: But what about in places like Memphis, where the governor has approved the use of the National Guard, or in the case of D.C., where the guard is technically under the president's control? Like, how does all of that fit here? LONSDORF: Yeah, in both D.C. and Memphis, Trump has sent in various federal agencies and National Guard troops to fight crime. And federal law enforcement officials have made a lot of arrests in both those places, but a significant portion of them have been immigration-related. I talked with Maria Oceja. She's in Memphis. She's a community organizer and immigration advocate there. She says while other people in the city might have focused on Trump's message about fighting crime, immigrant communities were skeptical. MARIA OCEJA: We have been tracking the messaging that has been coming out of the White House, and so we are not fooled by this language of, oh, we're only going to Memphis to fight crime. LONSDORF: She says there's been a lot of confusion and fear in the community there. The guard's actual role in immigration enforcement in these deployments remains unclear. Again, they cannot legally make arrests. In D.C., they've mainly been cleaning up streets and guarding federal buildings. CHANG: OK. Well, Sergio, I know that you've been talking to people in Chicago all week. What have you been hearing from them? MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: Yeah. I mean, a lot of U.S.-born residents tell us that they are angry. They don't want the National Guard or federal immigration agents in their communities, especially because their tactics have become more aggressive, leading to the arrest of some U.S. citizens. And for undocumented immigrants, the terror is real. I talked to Jackson (ph), a Venezuelan immigrant who did not want us to use his last name because of his legal status. JACKSON: (Speaking Spanish). MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: He says that it's already been scary and challenging to live in the city where you don't know if the masked person arresting you is ICE or someone pretending to be. And with the National Guard in town, Jackson says it will be even worse. CHANG: That is NPR's Sergio Martínez-Beltrán in Chicago and Kat Lonsdorf in D.C. Thank you to both of you. LONSDORF: Thanks, Ailsa. MARTÍNEZ-BELTRÁN: You're welcome.

articles.title: China Accuses U.S. Cyber Agency of Targeting National Time Center
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China accused the U.S. National Security Agency of conducting a series of cyberattacks between 2022 and 2024 on its National Time Service Center, claiming that the attacks exploited vulnerabilities in foreign messaging apps and used 42 specialized cyber weapons to infiltrate internal systems and steal sensitive data. The National Time Service Center is critical to China’s time standards and supports vital industries including finance, power, and defense. China stated it has evidence but did not provide it publicly. The U.S. did not respond directly, but previously claimed China is the most active cyber threat to U.S. interests. The incident highlights escalating cyber tensions between the two nations, raising concerns about global digital security and strategic competition.

The incident may escalate tensions between China and the U.S. over cyber warfare and national security issues.

ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE (AP) — President  Donald Trump  said Sunday that the United States could purchase Argentinian beef in an attempt to bring down prices for American consumers. “We would buy some beef from Argentina,” he told reporters aboard Air Force One during a flight from Florida to Washington. “If we do that, that will bring our beef prices down.” Trump promised earlier this week to address the issue as part of his efforts to keep inflation in check. U.S. beef  prices have been stubbornly high  for a variety of reasons, including drought and reduced imports from Mexico due to a flesh-eating pest in cattle herds there. Trump has been working to help  Argentina bolster its collapsing currency  with a $20 billion credit swap line and additional financing from sovereign funds and the private sector ahead of midterm elections for his close ally, President Javier Milei.

articles.title: Shooting at Oklahoma State University Student Party Wounds Three, No Arrests Made

The incident began with a disagreement at the Carreker East student apartments and spread to a parking lot and nearby street. Police responded after a report of a person collapsing at a McDonald’s and received calls of shots. No arrests have been made, though investigators have 'some solid leads' and are seeking public input. University police chief Michael Beckner confirmed no ongoing threat to campus or public safety. The event highlights vulnerabilities in student social environments and raises concerns about campus safety and mental health among young people.

Published: 2025-10-19T14:28:47+00:00

STILLWATER, Okla. (AP) — An argument at a private off-campus party escalated into a shooting outside an Oklahoma State University residence hall early Sunday, wounding three people including a student, school police said. Two victims were hospitalized in stable condition after surgery and the third was treated and released, university police Chief Michael Beckner told reporters. No arrests have been made, but he said said police have “some solid leads” and are asking for the public’s help. Investigators do not believe there’s an ongoing threat to the campus or public. The shooting erupted in an outdoor hallway at the Carreker East student apartments and spilled into a parking lot and nearby street, Beckner said, following a “disagreement between several people” at the party. Officers responded after a report of a person collapsing from injuries at a McDonald’s restaurant and calls of shots on campus, he said. When officers arrived on campus at about 3:40 a.m., no victims remained at the scene. Officers secured the area and took about 20 people present to a secure location for their safety and to begin interviews, the chief said.  The university is located in the city of Stillwater, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) northeast of Oklahoma City.

articles.title: The test for U.S. citizenship is about to get harder
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration is implementing significant changes to the U.S. naturalization process, making the oral civics exam more difficult by increasing the number of correct answers required from 6 out of 10 to 12 out of 20, expanding the pool of possible questions from 100 to 128, and replacing basic geography and holiday questions with more complex historical ones—such as those about the Persian Gulf and Vietnam Wars. These changes are aimed at ensuring applicants are 'fully assimilated' and aligned with American values. USCIS officials argue the test was previously 'too easy,' while critics, including legal scholar Amanda Frost and advocacy groups like the Central American Resource Center, warn that these changes may disproportionately affect low-literacy individuals, reduce naturalization rates, and lack empirical support for claims of allowing unfit citizens to join the nation. The changes also require applicants to prove 'good moral character' through tangible evidence of contributions to society, with possible background checks involving coworkers or neighbors.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration is making the U.S. citizenship oral exam harder by requiring green card holders to answer 12 out of 20 questions correctly, up from 6 out of 10.
The list of possible questions is expanding from 100 to 128, with a significant increase in difficulty and fewer basic geography or holiday-related questions.
Questions like 'Why did the U.S. enter the Persian Gulf War?' and 'Why did the U.S. enter the Vietnam War?' are replacing easier, more superficial ones.
Applicants must now demonstrate 'good moral character' by providing evidence of positive contributions to American society, with possible interviews of coworkers, family, or neighbors.
USCIS Director Joseph Edlow claims the current test is 'too easy' and that more rigorous questions are needed to ensure applicants have a true attachment to the Constitution.
Critics, including immigration law professor Amanda Frost, argue there is no evidence that the naturalization process allows individuals who do not share core American values to become citizens.
Advocacy groups warn that these changes disproportionately impact low-literacy individuals and those without access to preparation materials, potentially reducing naturalization rates.
The changes reflect broader policy goals of the Trump administration to limit immigration and ensure new citizens are 'fully assimilated' and aligned with U.S. values.

articles.content:
The test for U.S. citizenship is about to get harder 
         By Adrian Florido 
        
           Thursday, October 16, 2025 • 3:52 PM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         The Trump administration is making it harder to pass the oral exam required for immigrants seeking naturalization as U.S. citizens.   The new test is also longer. Green card holders who file for citizenship after Oct. 20 will have to answer twice as many questions correctly during the civics interview that tests their knowledge of U.S. history, politics and government and that is one of the final steps in the naturalization process. The list of possible questions will also get longer and include more difficult questions. A spokesman for U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), Matthew Tragesser, said in  a statement  when the changes were announced recently that the new test will ensure "that those joining us as fellow citizens are fully assimilated and will contribute to America's greatness." It's just one of several changes the Trump administration has instituted to make citizenship harder to earn as it seeks more broadly to limit the ability of immigrants and visa holders to enter, remain or settle in the U.S. The citizenship test that USCIS has used  since 2008  requires applicants to answer six questions correctly out of 10. The  new test  will require 12 correct answers out of 20. The list of possible questions the agent chooses from will grow from 100 to 128, and many will be more difficult. Questions about U.S. holidays and geography and others with short answers – "What ocean is on the West Coast of the United States?" – are being reduced or eliminated, and replaced with tougher ones: "Why did the United States enter the Persian Gulf War?" (Answer, according to the study guide: "To force the Iraqi military from Kuwait.") Another new question: Why did the United States enter the Vietnam War? (Answer, according to the study guide: "To stop the spread of communism.") Aside from the tougher civics test, applicants for citizenship will also have to convince an immigration officer that they have "good moral character." Until now, the absence of bad behavior or criminal conduct on an applicant's record has been enough. Now, they'll need to submit evidence of their "positive contributions to American society." Immigration officers will also more rigorously check applicants' backgrounds, possibly interviewing co-workers, family members or neighbors. Advocates who help people prepare for the citizenship test say the changes present more obstacles in an already challenging and cumbersome process. "It's hard to imagine that these changes don't have a negative impact on the number of people who are able to continue the naturalization process," said Julie Mitchell, legal director of the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles, which offers citizenship courses. "Particularly considering that these changes will impact individuals with low literacy levels and those who don't have access to classes and preparation materials." She said the naturalization process could also become more uncertain, because it's unclear what standards immigration officers will use to assess "good moral character." Speaking in Washington  last month , USCIS Director Joseph Edlow said that the current test is "just too easy" because some questions require simple answers, like naming the governor of an applicant's home state, or two federal holidays. "We need to know more," Edlow said. "Especially if we're going to really understand whether someone has a true attachment to the Constitution as required by the statute." But Amanda Frost, a professor of immigration law at the University of Virginia and the author of  You Are Not American , a book about the history of citizenship stripping, said that while requiring applicants for citizenship to jump over hurdles is appropriate, there's no proof that the existing naturalization process is falling short. "Has there been any evidence that we're allowing people to naturalize who don't share our values, and don't make for good participants in our democracy?" Frost asked. "I don't see any evidence of that." She notes that nearly  half of all Fortune 500  companies were founded by immigrants or their children. "Those who naturalize, and their children, thrive in the United States, and have benefited this country," Frost said. 
         
         Transcript 
         MARY LOUISE KELLY, HOST:   The Trump administration is making it harder for immigrants to become naturalized U.S. citizens. Starting next week, it is rolling out changes to the civics test that candidates for citizenship are required to pass. This is one of several changes the administration says are aimed at making sure new U.S. citizens are - in its words - fully assimilated. We're joined now by NPR's Adrian Florido. And Adrian, just explain the process here. The civics test is the last - one of the last steps in the naturalization process. Applicants go into an immigration office. They get asked a bunch of questions by the agent. If they pass, they usually earn their citizenship. And that process is not changing, right? ADRIAN FLORIDO, BYLINE: That's right, Mary Louise. That process is staying the same. What is changing is that applicants will now have to answer more questions correctly to pass that test. So with the current test, they have to get right 6 out of 10 questions that the agent asks them. They'll now have to get twice as many right - 12 out of up to 20 possible questions. And the list of possible questions that they will have to study from is also going to get quite a lot longer, so there'll be a lot more answers to memorize before you go in for the test. Citizenship and Immigration Services, USCIS, is also eliminating what are seen as easier questions on this test - so those about geography. For example, what ocean is on the West Coast of the U.S.? That question is out, and it's being replaced with questions like, why did the U.S. enter the Persian Gulf War? The right answer, according to the government, is - was to force the Iraqi military from Kuwait. The idea, Mary Louise, is to make this test harder to pass. KELLY: And why do this? Why does the Trump administration say these changes are needed? FLORIDO: Well, USCIS has said that they're about restoring, quote, "integrity" to the naturalization process. They're saying that the test is too easy. But these changes also reflect broader principles that President Trump has embraced about, you know, what it means to be a good American. A USCIS spokesman said in a statement that U.S. citizenship should only be for people who, quote, "fully embrace our values and principles as a nation." And he said that this new test will ensure that new citizens are, quote, "fully assimilated and will contribute to America's greatness." The naturalization process is also changing in other ways, Mary Louise. USCIS is requiring applicants to prove that they are of, quote, "good moral character" by providing evidence of positive contributions that they've made to the U.S. And immigration officers are also going to do more rigorous background checks on applicants, including possibly interviewing their coworkers, neighbors or family members. KELLY: So go back to something we just heard in that statement from the immigration official - the term fully assimilated. What does that mean? FLORIDO: You know, it's not new that the naturalization process requires a certain amount of integration, or you might say assimilation, into U.S. society. Most applicants have to speak English well enough to answer questions about U.S. history and government, for example. But the government is now saying that the bar is too low. I asked University of Virginia law professor Amanda Frost, who wrote a book about citizenship called "You Are Not American" - I asked her for her take on that claim. AMANDA FROST: Has there been any evidence that we have held that standard too low - that we're allowing people to naturalize who don't share values, don't make for good participants in our democracy and our society? And I would say I don't see any evidence of that. Those that naturalize and their children thrive in the United States and have benefited this country. KELLY: Well, so Adrian, what are the possible consequences of these changes? FLORIDO: Well, it's becoming harder to earn U.S. citizenship. And one big question about these questions, Mary Louise, is whether they'll drive down naturalization rates. And it's going to take some time to answer that question, but it's something that folks who help people through the citizenship process worry could happen. KELLY: That's NPR's Adrian Florido. Thank you, Adrian. FLORIDO: Thank you, Mary Louise.

articles.title: China’s Leadership to Finalize 2026–2030 Five-Year Plan Ahead of U.S. Trade Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: China’s leadership, led by President Xi Jinping, is gathering for the fourth plenary session of the Chinese Communist Party to finalize the national five-year plan for 2026–2030. This closed-door meeting comes amid heightened trade tensions with the United States, especially under former President Donald Trump’s trade policies, and as China seeks to achieve technological self-sufficiency in areas like artificial intelligence and advanced chip manufacturing. While the economy is projected to grow at 4.8%, challenges from a slowing property sector, overcapacity in industries, and low consumer confidence persist. Experts suggest that bolder policy actions are needed to stimulate domestic consumption and address long-term demographic pressures, including a youth unemployment rate of nearly 19%. The plan, though likely to follow previous formats, is critical to China’s political legitimacy and its goal of doubling economic size by 2035.
keyTakeAways: The fourth plenary session of the Chinese Communist Party will finalize the blueprint for China’s five-year plan (2026–2030), with leaders including Xi Jinping participating.
China’s economy is projected to grow at 4.8% this year, near its official 5% target, but faces slowing growth, trade tensions, and domestic challenges such as property sector downturns.

Key priorities include boosting consumer spending, curbing industrial overcapacity, and advancing technological self-sufficiency — especially in AI and advanced chip technologies — amid U.S. export controls and tariffs.
China is facing demographic pressures, including an aging population and a youth unemployment rate of nearly 19% among 16–24 year-olds.
The leadership remains committed to economic growth and national legitimacy, emphasizing stability and continued improvement in quality of life despite structural challenges.

articles.title: Blue Jays Edge Mariners in Game 7 to Advance to World Series
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Seattle Mariners 6-2 in a dramatic Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, advancing to the World Series. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his sixth postseason home run, tying the record for most in Blue Jays history, while rookie pitcher Trey Yesavage delivered a strong performance, including three double plays and seven strikeouts. The Blue Jays, who had lost four consecutive postseason games before this series, turned a critical defensive moment into a victory by forcing the Mariners into multiple errors. The Mariners, who have never won a pennant, are now facing their first Game 7 in franchise history. The Blue Jays’ victory marks a historic moment for the Guerrero family, as Vladimir Guerrero Jr. becomes the first in his lineage to reach a Game 7. The next game is scheduled for Monday, with Toronto starting Shane Bieber and Seattle starting George Kirby.
keyTakeAways: The Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Seattle Mariners 6-2 in a pivotal Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, pushing the series to a decisive conclusion.
Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his sixth postseason home run, tying him with José Bautista and Joe Carter for the most in Blue Jays history.
Rookie pitcher Trey Yesavage recorded seven strikeouts and three double plays, including two consecutive bases-loaded inning-ending double plays, marking a historic defensive feat in postseason play.
The Blue Jays have made only four errors in 10 playoff games, demonstrating strong defensive discipline.
The Mariners, who have never won a pennant, are making their first appearance in a Game 7, highlighting the significance of the matchup for their franchise history.
The Blue Jays are set to face the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series beginning Friday, after the ALCS conclusion.

This game marks the first time a Blue Jays player has reached a postseason Game 7, with Vladimir Guerrero Jr. being the first to do so in his family lineage — his father, Vladimir Guerrero, never played in a Game 7 during his career.

articles.title: Trump Administration Appeals to Supreme Court Over National Guard Deployment in Chicago and Memphis
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration has escalated its conflict with Democratic governors by seeking emergency approval from the Supreme Court to deploy National Guard troops in Illinois and Tennessee, particularly in Chicago and Memphis, amid ongoing immigration enforcement actions. A federal judge in Illinois blocked the deployment, citing no evidence of rebellion, while the administration argues the order infringes on presidential authority. In Memphis, Republican Governor Bill Lee has deployed Guard troops to combat violent crime, drawing criticism from local Democratic officials who claim it violates state constitutional limits. Similar legal challenges have emerged in Oregon and California, where federal judges have also blocked Guard deployments. The conservative-leaning Supreme Court has previously supported Trump’s executive actions, including military-related decisions, suggesting a broader trend of federal executive power asserting itself against judicial and state-level constraints.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration sought emergency intervention from the Supreme Court to allow the deployment of National Guard troops in Chicago and Memphis, challenging a federal judge’s decision to block such actions.
U.S. District Judge April Perry ruled that there was no substantial evidence of rebellion in Illinois, preventing Guard deployment for at least two weeks.
The Solicitor General D. John Sauer argued that the judge’s order infringes on presidential authority and endangers federal personnel and property.
In Memphis, Tennessee, Republican Governor Bill Lee, with Trump’s support, deployed National Guard troops amid concerns over violent crime, citing a need for public safety.
The deployment in Memphis has drawn criticism from Democratic officials who claim it violates the state constitution and sets a dangerous precedent for federal military involvement.

A federal judge in Oregon previously blocked National Guard deployment at a Broadview ICE facility, and similar legal challenges have emerged in California, where a judge ruled against the deployment in Los Angeles.

The Supreme Court, which is conservative-dominated, has previously granted Trump repeated victories in emergency appeals, including banning transgender service members and firing federal agency leaders.
The conflict reflects broader political tensions over executive authority, state sovereignty, and the use of military forces on U.S. soil during immigration enforcement.

articles.title: Nevada Unions Push for Film Tax Credits to Boost Tourism and Jobs
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Nevada labor unions, through the political action committee Nevada Jobs Now, are pushing state officials to approve tax credits for Sony Pictures Entertainment and Warner Bros. Discovery to build a $4.5 billion film production facility, Summerlin Studios, in West Las Vegas. The project would create 19,000 construction jobs and attract new tourists by offering a cinematic destination akin to Atlanta’s 'Hollywood of the South.' However, critics, including the AFSCME union, argue the plan is fiscally irresponsible, generating only $0.52 in tax revenue per dollar spent and diverting funds from public services. The proposal faces uncertainty as Governor Joe Lombardo has scheduled a special session in 2025 to debate the issue, with economic, political, and public service concerns at stake.
keyTakeAways: Nevada labor unions are advocating for tax credits to bring Hollywood film production to Las Vegas, aiming to boost tourism and create 19,000 construction jobs.

The proposed Summerlin Studios project by Sony Pictures Entertainment and Warner Bros. Discovery would include 10 movie stages, hotels, a medical center, and a mixed-use community in West Las Vegas, with $4.5 billion in total investment over 15 years.
To qualify for tax credits, $400 million must be spent on construction and $1.8 billion on the mixed-use development, with eligibility tied to the start of filming.
The film industry is a major economic driver, as seen in Atlanta, where tax incentives led to increased tourism, production, and jobs—though at a significant cost to state finances.

Critics, including the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), argue the proposal is fiscally irresponsible, claiming it would generate only $0.52 in tax revenue per dollar spent and divert funds from public services.
Supporters claim film studios would attract a new type of tourist and create long-term economic benefits, especially given Las Vegas’ current tourism decline.
The Nevada Jobs Now political action committee has raised over $1 million to promote the proposal through digital ads and mailers.

articles.title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivia’s Presidential Election Amid Economic Crisis
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator who rose from political obscurity, won Bolivia’s presidential election with 54% of the vote, defeating former President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45%. The victory marks a significant shift away from two decades of Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) rule, driven by public anger over economic collapse, inflation, and the perceived mismanagement of public resources. Paz’s campaign, backed by his running mate Edman Lara — a former police officer known for anti-corruption activism — resonated with working-class and Indigenous voters, especially in the Andean highlands. However, the new government faces immense challenges, including a severe dollar shortage, fuel shortages, and a 23% inflation rate. Paz has pledged to end the fixed exchange rate, cut fuel subsidies, and reduce public spending, while avoiding the IMF and promising gradual reforms. Though he aims to maintain social benefits, his vague promises of financial support have drawn criticism. The election reflects a deep class divide, with Paz winning among rural and Indigenous communities and Quiroga among wealthier, politically entrenched elites in Santa Cruz. This shift signals a potential turning point in Bolivia’s economic and political trajectory, though the success of reforms remains uncertain.
keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz won Bolivia's presidential election with 54% of the vote, defeating former President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga who received 45%.
Paz, a centrist senator from the Christian Democratic Party, emerged from obscurity to win, representing a significant political shift away from the long-ruling Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party.
Paz’s victory reflects widespread public frustration with economic mismanagement, inflation, and the perceived unresponsiveness of the MAS government over 20 years.
Paz’s running mate, former police officer Edman Lara, gained traction through viral social media presence and anti-corruption activism, resonating with working-class and rural voters.

Paz plans to end Bolivia’s fixed exchange rate, reduce fuel subsidies, and cut public investment, marking a shift from MAS’s economic model, while promising to maintain social benefits and implement reforms gradually.
Bolivia faces severe economic challenges, including a 23% year-on-year inflation rate, fuel shortages, and a dollar shortage that has crippled imports and savings.
Paz has pledged to avoid the International Monetary Fund, instead relying on anti-corruption measures and restoring confidence in the currency to attract foreign savings.
Criticism exists over Paz’s vague promises of financial support for the poor during subsidy cuts, with some voters calling for more concrete economic reforms.
The election reflects a clear class divide: Paz won in Indigenous and working-class regions, while Quiroga won among wealthier, politically established elites in Santa Cruz.
The victory marks a potential shift toward a more market-oriented economy in Bolivia after two decades of MAS-led socialist policies.

articles.title: Trump Slashes U.S. Aid to Colombia, Accuses Petro of Drug Links
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has escalated tensions with Colombia by cutting U.S. aid and imposing new tariffs, accusing President Gustavo Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and failing to stop drug production. The U.S. conducted a military strike on a vessel linked to the National Liberation Army (ELN), which Colombia disputes, alleging it targeted a civilian fisherman, Alejandro Carranza. Petro rejected the accusations, asserting he is the primary force fighting drug trafficking and calling U.S. actions a violation of sovereignty. The article highlights deepening friction between the U.S. and Colombia amid rising drug cultivation, regional instability, and concerns over the erosion of military cooperation, with experts warning of serious strategic consequences.

articles.title: Thousands Protest at Israeli Consulate Over Military Draft for Ultra-Orthodox Jews
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 20, 2025, thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews gathered in New York City to protest Israel’s decision to end a long-standing exemption from military conscription for religious students. The protest, which took place at the Israeli consulate near the United Nations campus, was organized in part by the Central Rabbinical Congress of the U.S.A. and Canada and supported by both grand rebbes of the Satmar community. The demonstration reflects deep religious and cultural tensions between religious freedom and state-mandated military service, especially in the context of Israel’s Supreme Court ruling in 2024 to begin drafting ultra-Orthodox men. The protest underscores the growing divide within the U.S. Jewish community, with religious leaders emphasizing the importance of studying Torah and living according to religious values, while the broader conflict over conscription has intensified since the Gaza war began.

The issue has become more polarized since the start of the Gaza war, with ultra-Orthodox Jews fearing loss of religious identity and Israeli citizens arguing that exemptions are unjust.
Rabbi Moishe Indig, a Satmar leader, emphasized the importance of freedom to study Torah and live according to religious values, framing the protest as a defense of religious liberty.

articles.title: Doug Martin, Former Tampa Bay Buccaneers Star, Dies at 36
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Doug Martin, a former All-Pro running back with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, has died at the age of 36. Selected 31st overall in the 2012 NFL draft from Boise State, Martin had a standout career with 5,356 rushing yards and 30 touchdowns, including a Pro Bowl and first-team All-Pro season in 2015. He also had 148 catches for 1,207 yards. The Buccaneers, which he played for for six seasons and one with the Raiders, expressed deep sorrow over his passing, and recognized him as one of the top 50 players in franchise history during the team's 50th anniversary celebration. The cause of death remains unconfirmed.

TAMPA, Fla. (AP) — Doug Martin, a former All-Pro running back with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, has died. He was 36. “It is with great sadness to inform you all that Doug Martin passed away Saturday morning. Cause of death is currently unconfirmed. Please respect our privacy at this time,” his family said in a statement to Fox Sports. Martin was picked 31st overall in the first round of the 2012 NFL draft after a standout career at Boise State. He rushed for 1,454 yards and 11 touchdowns as a rookie to earn a Pro Bowl berth. He had 1,402 yards rushing and six TDs in 2015 when he made the Pro Bowl and was first-team All-Pro. Martin finished his career with 5,356 yards rushing and 30 TDs in six seasons with the Buccaneers and one with the Raiders. He also had 148 catches for 1,207 yards and two scores. The  Buccaneers issued a statement,  saying: “We are deeply saddened to learn of the sudden and unexpected passing of Doug Martin. ... Doug made a lasting impact on our franchise.” Martin was selected one of the top 50 players in franchise history as part of the team’s 50 year anniversary celebration. ___ AP NFL:  https://apnews.com/hub/nfl

articles.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree to Immediate Ceasefire, Mediated by Qatar and Turkey
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire mediated by Qatar and Turkey, ending weeks of escalating violence along their 2,611-kilometer border. The agreement prohibits hostile actions, support of militant groups, and attacks on civilians or critical infrastructure. Both countries commit to respecting each other’s sovereignty and holding a follow-up meeting in Istanbul on October 25 to review implementation. Key border crossings, including Chaman and Torkham, remain closed, disrupting trade and affecting thousands of refugees and local businesses. While the Taliban’s chief spokesman and Pakistani defense ministers confirmed the agreement, concerns remain about economic recovery and long-term peace. The conflict, rooted in disputed sovereignty over the Durand Line and rising militancy since 2021, has severely impacted civilians, with humanitarian and trade consequences.
keyTakeAways: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to an immediate ceasefire mediated by Qatar and Turkey.
The ceasefire prohibits hostile actions, support for militant groups, and attacks on civilians or critical infrastructure.
The truce is intended to pause hostilities and allow for the implementation of a future mechanism to review bilateral claims.
Both countries agreed to respect each other’s sovereignty and territorial integrity.
The Doha talks lasted 13 hours and were attended by top officials from both nations.
The Torkham and Chaman border crossings remain closed, impacting trade and refugee movements.
Afghanistan denies harboring militants who carry out attacks in border areas.
Pakistan is dealing with a surge in militancy since 2021, following the Taliban’s return to power.
The Taliban government’s chief spokesman, Zabihullah Mujahid, expressed positive views on the agreement.
Pakistani Defense Minister Muhammad Yaqoob confirmed the duration of the Doha talks.
Pakistani Defense Minister Khawaja Asif publicly confirmed the agreement on social media, emphasizing the end of cross-border terrorism.
Afghan refugees and local traders are expressing relief and concern over the reopening of trade routes.

articles.title: Trump Proposes Cutting Up Donbas Region, Ukraine Faces Escalation in Drone Attacks on Russian Energy Facilities
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has proposed that the Donbas region of Ukraine be 'cut up' and left in Russian hands as a condition for ending the war, shifting U.S. policy from earlier support for Ukraine’s territorial recovery. This comes amid escalating drone attacks: Ukrainian forces struck a major gas processing plant in Russia’s Orenburg region, damaging operations and disrupting gas intake from Kazakhstan; in response, Russia launched attacks on Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, including Kharkiv and Dnipropetrovsk, and on the Novokuibyshevsk refinery. Ukraine claims it has also used long-range drones to target Russian facilities, while Russia claims it shot down 45 Ukrainian drones. Trump did not commit to providing Ukraine with Tomahawk missiles, contrary to Kyiv’s expectations. The article highlights the deepening of military actions, shifting U.S. diplomatic positions, and the increasing use of long-range weapons in a war that has lasted nearly four years.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump has suggested that the Donbas region of Ukraine should be 'cut up' and left largely in Russian hands as part of a peace settlement, indicating a shift from previous support for Ukraine’s territorial recovery.

Ukrainian drones struck a major gas processing plant in Russia’s Orenburg region, damaging operations and causing a temporary suspension of gas intake from Kazakhstan, highlighting ongoing energy attacks.
Russia has retaliated with drone attacks on Ukrainian cities, including Kharkiv and Dnipropetrovsk, and on Russian infrastructure like the Novokuibyshevsk refinery, showing continued escalation.
Trump reportedly downplayed support for Ukraine receiving long-range Tomahawk missiles, contradicting Kyiv’s hopes for significant U.S. military aid.
Russia has been accused of modifying aerial bombs (like the UMPB-5R) for deeper strikes into Ukrainian territory, increasing civilian risk and war intensity.

articles.title: Travis Hunter Makes First NFL Touchdown in Jaguars’ Loss to Rams at Wembley
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Travis Hunter, the 2024 Heisman Trophy winner and Jacksonville Jaguars' rookie star, made his first NFL touchdown in a dramatic moment during a 35-7 loss to the Los Angeles Rams at Wembley Stadium. Despite being down 28-0, Hunter fought through contact to score on a 34-yard reception, showcasing his resilience and skill. The Jaguars struggled throughout the game due to poor discipline—13 penalties for 119 yards, including an illegal block by Jarrian Jones that nullified a potential touchdown and a key drop by Brian Thomas Jr.—and missed a crucial 50-yard field goal by Cam Little. Head coach Liam Coen emphasized the team’s intent to involve Hunter more in the offense, noting the difficulty of establishing rhythm early. Trevor Lawrence of the Rams praised Hunter’s ability to make plays under pressure, highlighting growing chemistry between the two teams. Hunter, who did not celebrate his touchdown, chose to give the ball to his son, underscoring his humility and focus on team effort.
keyTakeAways: Travis Hunter, the 2024 Heisman Trophy winner and Jacksonville Jaguars' star rookie, recorded his first NFL touchdown with a 34-yard reception in the second half after the team was trailing 28-0.
Hunter made the play despite being held up by defenders, showing resilience and skill, and opted not to celebrate, instead giving the touchdown ball to his son.
Hunter finished the game with eight receptions for 101 yards, marking his best performance as a professional player.
Trevor Lawrence of the Los Angeles Rams acknowledged Hunter's ability to make plays under pressure, citing strong chemistry and game awareness.
Jacksonville’s offensive struggles were highlighted by a slow start, poor discipline (13 penalties for 119 yards), and key mistakes including a drop by Brian Thomas Jr. and a missed field goal.
Head coach Liam Coen emphasized the team's intent to involve Hunter more in the offense and acknowledged the difficulty of establishing rhythm early in the game.
The Jaguars ultimately lost 35-7 to the Rams at Wembley Stadium, underscoring the challenges of maintaining consistency and discipline in high-pressure games.

articles.title: Plan to fire artillery over a highway during Vance visit irks California’s Newsom
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: During a Marine Corps anniversary exercise at Camp Pendleton, California, a 155 mm artillery shell prematurely detonated overhead, sending shrapnel that damaged a California Highway Patrol vehicle and left a piece of metal on a patrol officer’s motorcycle. The incident occurred despite Governor Gavin Newsom’s objections and the closure of a 17-mile stretch of Interstate 5 for safety. Vice President JD Vance, a former Marine, was present to observe the demonstration. The Marine Corps suspended further firing, launched an investigation into the cause of the premature detonation, and confirmed no injuries. Newsom criticized the event as a 'vanity project' endangering public lives, while officials emphasized adherence to safety protocols.
keyTakeAways: Live artillery rounds were fired over Interstate 5 during a Marine Corps exercise at Camp Pendleton, California, despite objections from Governor Gavin Newsom over safety concerns.
Metal shrapnel from an exploding artillery shell damaged a California Highway Patrol vehicle and left a small dent and scratch on its hood.
A patrol officer reported hearing a sound like pebbles falling and found a piece of shrapnel near his motorcycle; no injuries occurred.
The Marine Corps suspended further firing after detecting a possible airborne detonation outside the designated impact zone.
An investigation has been launched to determine the root cause of the premature detonation.
Governor Gavin Newsom strongly opposed the exercise, closed a 17-mile stretch of I-5, and criticized Vice President JD Vance and the White House for endangering public safety for 'vanity projects'.
Vice President JD Vance, a former Marine and Iraq veteran, visited Camp Pendleton to observe a beach assault demonstration as part of the Marine Corps' 250th-anniversary events.
The incident raised concerns about military safety protocols, public exposure to live ordnance, and the balance between national defense demonstrations and civilian safety.

articles.title: Mahomes' Ruse Leads Chiefs to 31-0 Shutout Victory Over Raiders
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a decisive 31-0 victory, the Kansas City Chiefs defeated the Las Vegas Raiders in a dominant performance, marking their most lopsided shutout in 133 previous matchups. The game featured a strategic ruse by Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes, who yelled in frustration during a critical fourth-and-1 situation, leading the Raiders to relax and misjudge the play. Mahomes then handed off to Kareem Hunt, who gained a first down, setting up a touchdown drive that ended in a decisive win. The Raiders struggled offensively, managing only three first downs, 96 yards, and 30 plays—among the worst in franchise history—while suffering multiple injuries to key players including Maxx Crosby, Adam Butler, Brock Bowers, and Jakobi Meyers. The Chiefs outperformed them in nearly every metric: 434 yards, 9-of-15 on third down, and 42 minutes of possession. The game highlighted the importance of team depth, injury management, and situational awareness in the NFL.
keyTakeAways: The Kansas City Chiefs defeated the Las Vegas Raiders 31-0 in a dominant performance, marking their most lopsided shutout against the Raiders in 133 meetings.
Patrick Mahomes used a ruse—yelling in frustration during a fourth-and-1 situation—to deceive the Raiders, who relaxed, allowing Mahomes to hand off to Kareem Hunt and gain a first down.
The Raiders struggled with offensive execution, managing only three first downs, 96 yards of total offense, and 30 plays—the second-fewest in Super Bowl era history.
The Chiefs outperformed the Raiders in multiple areas: 434 yards of total offense, 9-of-15 on third down, and 42 minutes of possession compared to the Raiders' 17 minutes.
Raiders injuries significantly impacted their performance: Brock Bowers, Jakobi Meyers, Maxx Crosby, and Adam Butler were ruled out or injured during the game.
The Chiefs' depth was evident as nine different players caught passes, including Travis Kelce, Xavier Worthy, Rashee Rice, and Marquise Brown.
Raiders quarterback Geno Smith had a poor game, going 10-of-16 for 67 yards and fumbling on his first snap; Kenny Pickett replaced him but immediately fumbled.
Patrick Mahomes humorously attributed his acting to 'all my State Farm commercials' after the game, drawing laughter from teammates and fans.
The Raiders' defensive struggles were highlighted, as Kansas City's speed and offensive cohesion overwhelmed their defense.
The game underscored the importance of team cohesion, injury management, and situational awareness in NFL football.

articles.title: Pope Leo XIV Canonizes Venezuela's 'Doctor of the Poor' as Nation's First Saint
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pope Leo XIV canonized José Gregorio Hernández, Venezuela’s beloved 'doctor of the poor,' as the nation’s first saint, in a ceremony that drew tens of thousands of people. This event, which also included the canonization of six other saints—such as Peter To Rot of Papua New Guinea, Archbishop Maloyan, and Sister Maria Troncatti—occurred amid Venezuela’s severe economic crisis, mass emigration, and rising tensions with the United States. Pope Francis had previously approved the decision in February 2025, bypassing the standard miracle confirmation process due to the widespread veneration of Hernández. The event was seen as a source of national pride and spiritual resilience, especially following the Nobel Peace Prize win by opposition leader María Corina Machado. Thousands of Venezuelans celebrated in Caracas, with the event reinforcing a deep cultural and religious identity in the face of ongoing hardship.
keyTakeAways: José Gregorio Hernández, a Venezuelan doctor known for treating the poor without charging fees, was canonized as a saint by Pope Leo XIV, marking Venezuela’s first saint and a major cultural milestone.
The canonization occurred amid Venezuela’s severe economic crisis, mass emigration, and rising tensions with the United States, providing a source of national pride and morale.
The ceremony included the canonization of six additional saints, including Peter To Rot of Papua New Guinea and Bartolo Longo, reflecting broader Catholic values of service and sacrifice.
Pope Francis, in a final act as pope, approved the canonization of Hernández based on widespread veneration rather than a miracle, highlighting a shift in canonization procedures.
The event drew massive public attention, with thousands of Venezuelans in Caracas watching the Mass live via a giant screen and celebrating with flags and patriotic displays.
The canonization coincides with political developments, such as María Corina Machado winning the Nobel Peace Prize, reinforcing its symbolic significance in Venezuela’s current national context.

articles.title: At least 37 people killed in flooding caused by tropical storms in Mexico
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical storms, including Raymond, Priscilla, and remnants of Octave, caused severe flooding in central and southeastern Mexico, resulting in at least 37 deaths and widespread damage to homes, roads, and power infrastructure. The Sierra Madre Oriental region was especially vulnerable due to landslides and blocked communities. Mexico deployed over 8,700 military personnel and emergency resources from the Secretariat of the Navy to provide aid, with significant impacts in Hidalgo, Puebla, Veracruz, and Queretaro. The event is linked to broader climate patterns such as La Nina, which may be increasing rainfall intensity across the region. The flooding underscores growing climate risks in Mexico due to persistent extreme weather in 2025.
keyTakeAways: At least 37 people have died in Mexico due to flooding from tropical storms, with the highest fatalities in Hidalgo (22), Puebla (9), and Veracruz (5).
Heavy rainfall affected 31 of 32 Mexican states, with the worst impacts in Veracruz, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
The Sierra Madre Oriental mountain range was identified as the main disaster area due to landslides and blocked communities.
Over 8,700 military personnel were deployed to assist in evacuation, monitoring, and cleanup operations.
The Secretariat of the Navy deployed 3,300 personnel, 18 vessels, 6 helicopters, 3 water purification plants, 3 aircraft, 3 mobile kitchens, and 4,000 food baskets to support emergency relief.
Over 80,000 people were affected in Puebla alone, with 1,000 homes damaged in Hidalgo and 5,000 homes damaged in Veracruz.
Power outages affected over 320,000 users, and nearly 1,000 km of roads were damaged across six states.
Tropical Storm Raymond is currently off the Pacific coast, expected to make landfall in southern Baja California over the weekend and weaken to a tropical depression by Sunday.
The return of La Nina, a Pacific cooling pattern, is being linked to increased rainfall and extreme weather events in Mexico.
This event is part of a broader pattern of extreme weather in Mexico in 2025, including a rainfall record in Mexico City.

Title: At least 37 people killed in flooding caused by tropical storms in Mexico

At least 37 people have died and others are missing in Mexico after flooding set off by heavy rainfall caused landslides and damaged homes and highways, authorities say.

Downpours in central and southeastern parts of the country led to overflowing rivers, road collapses and power cuts in some municipalities, the national coordinator for civil defence, Laura Velazquez, said on Friday.

Civil defence authorities reported intense rainfall in 31 of 32 states with the worst affected areas being Veracruz in the east, Queretaro and Hidalgo in the centre, and the north-central state of San Luis Potosi.

Authorities in Hidalgo reported at least 22 people dead, 1,000 homes damaged and 90 communities inaccessible to rescuers, the federal security secretariat said.

It said at least nine people died in neighbouring Puebla state. About 80,000 people have been affected by the extreme weather in Puebla alone, the state government said.

In the state of Veracruz on the Gulf of Mexico, five people died, including a police officer, according to its state governor. About 5,000 homes were damaged, and the navy evacuated nearly 900 people to shelters.

Earlier, authorities in Queretaro confirmed that a child had died after being caught in a landslide.

The heavy rainfall also caused power outages affecting more than 320,000 users and damage to almost 1,000km (621 miles) of roads in six states, authorities said.

Tras las fuertes lluvias, la Secretaría de Marina ( @SEMAR_mx  ) desplegó tres mil 300 elementos en Puebla, Veracruz y San Luis Potosí.

También puso a disposición 18 embarcaciones, seis helicópteros, tres plantas potabilizadoras, tres aviones, tres cocinetas y cuatro mil…  pic.twitter.com/O7ES5XBoKC

— Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo (@Claudiashein)  October 11, 2025

Translation: After the heavy rains, the Secretariat of the Navy ( @SEMAR_mx  ) deployed 300 personnel in Puebla, Veracruz and San Luis Potosí. It also made available 18 vessels, six helicopters, three water purification plants, three aircraft, three mobile kitchens and 4,000 food baskets ready to be distributed.

“We are working to support the population, open roads and restore electrical services,” President Claudia Sheinbaum said after a meeting with local officials and cabinet members. She shared photos of emergency responders carrying supplies as they waded knee-deep in flooded streets.

The country has deployed more than 8,700 military personnel to help monitor, evacuate and clean up affected areas. Shelters were open for those displaced from their homes.

The main disaster area has been Sierra Madre Oriental, a mountain range that runs parallel to the Gulf of Mexico coast. It is dotted by small communities, many of which were blocked off on Friday.

Mexico has been hit by particularly heavy rains throughout 2025, and a rainfall record was set in the capital, Mexico City.

Tropical Storm Raymond is currently off the country’s Pacific coast, dumping heavy rains as it moves northwards. It is projected to make landfall in Mexico on Sunday.

Raymond was announced on Thursday by the United States National Hurricane Center, making it the third system this week off the western coast of Mexico. It joined Tropical Storm Priscilla and post-Tropical Cyclone Octave, which threatened heavy rains and flooding in their paths.

Authorities in areas on the Pacific coast on Saturday were continuing to keep a close eye on Raymond and remnants of Priscilla.

Both storms dumped heavy rains on western Mexico, causing damage in Chiapas, Guerrero, Oaxaca and Michoacan states.

Meteorologists have warned that the Pacific Ocean cooling pattern called La Nina, which can warp weather worldwide and turbocharge hurricanes, has returned.

It may be too late in the hurricane season to impact tropical weather in the Atlantic, but this La Nina may have other impacts from heavy rains to drought across the globe.

Raymond is expected to hit the southern part of Baja California over the weekend, according to the US National Hurricane Center, and is forecast to weaken to a tropical depression by Sunday.

Title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing

Torrential flooding has continued to sweep parts of central and southeastern Mexico, raising the death toll to at least 44 people in less than a week.

Heavy downpours caused by two tropical storms have  triggered landslides and flooding  across five states, including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro and San Luis Potosi, the government said in a statement on Sunday.

Floods have killed 18 people in Veracruz state, 16 in Hidalgo, nine in Puebla and one in Queretaro, the statement said.

Mexico’s El Universal newspaper put the death toll even higher — at 48 — and reported that dozens remain missing.

Around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged, according to authorities, who fear that more landslides and overflowing rivers could exacerbate the damage.

President Claudia Sheinbaum said the military has been mobilised to help with rescue operations and aid distributions. “We will not leave anyone without support,” she said in a post on X.

Photos posted by the military showed people being evacuated by soldiers with life rafts, homes flooded with mud, and rescue workers trudging through waist-high waters.

Mexico has been hit by particularly heavy rains this year, and Mexico City recorded its rainiest June in more than two decades.

Authorities have attributed the latest deadly downpours to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, both of which dumped heavy rains on Mexico’s west.

The remnants of Raymond, with wind gusts now at 45km/hr (28mph), were expected to hit the southern part of Baja California on Sunday.

Title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing

At least 64 people have died in Mexico after heavy rains and flooding hit five states last week.

The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, speaking during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily news briefing on Monday, said another 65 people were still missing.

The state of Veracruz on the country’s southeastern coastline has confirmed 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla and one in Queretaro, Alzua said.

Forty-three people are also reported missing in Hidalgo, along with 18 in Veracruz and four in Puebla.

Thousands of military troops have been deployed to offer assistance across the five affected states, and governors are also working together to coordinate support, Sheinbaum said.

Early estimates show that about 100,000 houses have been affected, she added, with some near rivers having “practically disappeared”.

Facing questions about Mexico’s alert system, Sheinbaum said there were no meteorological signs “that could have indicated to us that the rain was going to be of this magnitude”.

Meteorologists have said the rains occurred thanks to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which caused rivers to rapidly rise, leading to flooding and landslides.

The heaviest rainfall was reported on Wednesday in Veracruz’s city of Cerro Azul and Puebla’s Cuetzalan del Progreso, which saw 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively, Alzua said.

The Mexican Army, Air Force and National Guard have jointly implemented response efforts, distributing food and clean water, sometimes by air, to locations otherwise made inaccessible by landslides and road closures.

Nearly 400 repair workers have restored more than 80 percent of the electricity supply across the five states, where about 263,000 users lost power, electricity officials said during the briefing.

articles.title: ‘We don’t want to disappear’: Tuvalu fights for climate action and survival
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tuvalu, a low-lying Pacific nation barely one meter above sea level, is urgently advocating for climate action and financial support to survive rising sea levels. As one of the most vulnerable nations to climate change, Tuvalu’s Minister of Climate Change, Maina Talia, emphasizes the urgent need for real, immediate climate finance—highlighting a global shortfall where small island states need $12 billion annually but receive only $2 billion. Tuvalu is pushing for stronger accountability under the polluter pays principle and leading global initiatives such as a fossil fuel non-proliferation treaty, with 16 countries now signed on. The country is also preparing for cultural extinction by creating a digital archive of its heritage, and is seeking full UNESCO World Heritage List inclusion. Tuvalu’s efforts are amplified by a 2025 ICJ ruling affirming state responsibility to combat climate change, and the nation sees COP30 in Belém, Brazil, as a critical moment to advance climate justice, demand financing, and counter the influence of oil-producing countries dominating climate negotiations.

The country is leading the development of a world-first fossil fuel non-proliferation treaty, with 16 countries now signed on, and Colombia set to host the first conference.
Tuvalu is preparing for cultural loss by creating a digital repository of its heritage, in case the nation disappears.

A 2025 ruling by the International Court of Justice affirmed states' duties to combat climate change and protect vulnerable nations, adding legal weight to Tuvalu’s demands.
